messages: 6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:09): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884: can you explain what you meant by "this version of HTML5"?
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:09): 6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514: I mean the next one being HTML6 or HTML5.1 or whatever

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:11): 6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514: in other words, I think <datagrid> is not right as it until recently was specified, and there is no time left to redesign it in the HTML5 cycle, but I'd like to see the feature come back in better form in a later version of HTML
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:11): understood
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:12): http://tinyurl.com/nw653o
0a39f78bcb297ab0ebe8a29c28bfed89 (00:12): Title: HTML5 Live DOM Viewer (at tinyurl.com)
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:13): I'm curious about things like how we can enable things like HTML5.next given how much HTML5 nails down the parsing rules.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:14): we just change the parsing rules
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:14): can't that break the web?
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:14): I think there's two cases:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:14): sure, you have to do it carefully
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:14): it's exactly like the html4-5 transition
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:14): 1) anything that we want to be parsed in the same way that an unknown element is parsed in HTML5 will work fine
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:15): the rules were nailed down for html4 too, it just wasn't written anywhere

139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:15): 2) anything that needs to be parsed differently, we need to do everything we can to verify that content doesn't depend on the behavior when treated as an unknown element
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:15): there was a wide variety of implementations on html4
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:16): first bar is inside of datagrid, second one is outside
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:16): 6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514: not anywhere near as wide as you might think
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:16): 6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514: I did, and I expect you were making a point, but I did not get what the point was (likely my lack of imagination)
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:17): I don't believe that #1 is the case.
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:17): I don't follow the logic..
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:18): are you saying this behavior for unknown elements would not ever be acceptable for a real element?
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:18): (in the face of unclosed tags, may I add)
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:19): Let's compromise :-)  How about s/not ever/unlikely to/
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (00:19): How is it unacceptable in your example?
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:20): I believe what's happening is that <zetagrid> is never closed, due to the lack of a close tag for <p>
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:20): but datagrid is closed by </datagrid>....
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:20): I claim that people have an unfortunate tendency to forget to correctly close tags.  I think I can back that up with evidence.
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:21): indeed, so datagrid doesn'
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:21): t parse the same as an unknown element
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:21): <span> parses the same as an unknown element (IIRC)
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:22): try <span><z>x</span><bar>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:22): a whole bunch of elements in html5 parse like unknown elements according to the HTML5 parsing rules
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:22): that's weird, why is there a difference between <datagrid> and <zetagrid>? Aren't both unknown elements in existing browsers?
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:23): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: HTML5 Live DOM Viewer
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:23): 6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514: if I replace zetagrid in your example with span, the parse tree is the same
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:23): assumed I was looking at the normal live dom viewer
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:23): 6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514: if I replace span with zetagrid in your second example, the parse tree is the same
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:23): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: you were phished!
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (00:23): I wonder how long until there's a formal objection to "an end tag whose tag name is sarcasm"
6132ec92889c0ce747ae9f7e44f90514 (00:25): ok, I see... picking <p> was unfortunate.
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (00:25): yes, some elements are supposed to have <p>-closing behavior that <span> and random unknown elements do not
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (00:30): Making the list of p-closing elements separate from the specification would probably be a lot of work for little gain too
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:31): all compat problems Opera has had so far has been with attributes, not new elements
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:32): (including <event-source>, <output>, <datalist>)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:32): have been*
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:33): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, did the issues graph ever function in Opera before you added the labels earlier today?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:33): yeah
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (00:34): Does it use the canvas text apis, maybe?

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:34): ok. I was trying to modify it to make it work in Opera by checking if the canvas text was supported or not before attempting to use it, but I can't get it to work

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:34): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, do you have a copy of it that works from before you added that stuff, so I can compare the two and see what changes you actually made?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (00:35): that would help me figure out what's wrong
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:50): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: i just removed all the checks for whether the text api is supported

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:51): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: (since i'd added code that relied on the text api without testing if it was supported, and it was easier to just take out all the checks than try to add more checks in)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:51): surely everyone supports the text apis by now
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:51): i don't have an old copy handy
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (00:52): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Did you handle the call to measureText too?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:59): someone who cares and follows the WS URL scheme debate should point out that if there's any renaming new names for both schemes need to be considered
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:00): websocks does not make me think of secure web sockets anyway
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:03): i don't really see the problem with ws: and wss:, but i haven't yet looked closely at the thread
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:05): There isn't anything more than "ws also means webservice" from what I saw
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:06): and someone was in favor of a readable scheme name, like mailto
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:07): I don't see how websocket is readable. Mail is a well known concept, but few people know sockets and even fewer would know what exactly a web socket is
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:08): but you could google it
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:09): or "ws protocol scheme"
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:10): I sort of wonder why a scheme is needed here btw
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:12): Is it possible to upgrade a FF major version, or do you have to download the new one normally?
0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (01:13): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: major updates are possible: just manually "check for updates"
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (01:13): "websock" is a silly name FOR A URI SCHEME
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:14): 0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3: Right, I found it eventually. It was hiding behind three minor updates to the previous version...
0c2de4934c6d7fc96160344dec846df3 (01:14): Ah yes, that _is_ annoying.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:15): "websock" -- some new kind of Nike-sock connected to the cloud
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:16): websock is winsock for the web
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:16): "websocks" -- when you have a pair of them
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:16): Yeah, if you need more connections
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:17): And every so often the server will lose one of a pair
